stories: having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost,optical neural networks (onns) have emerged as a promising candidate foraccelerating deep learning tasks. in conventional onns, light amplitudes aremodulated at the input and detected at the output. however, the light phasesare still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carryinformation for computing. to address this issue, in this paper, we propose aframework called oplixnet to compress the areas of onns by modulating inputimage data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. the input andoutput parts of the onns are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude andphase information. moreover, mutual learning across different onn structures isintroduced to maintain the accuracy. experimental results demonstrate that theproposed framework significantly reduces the areas of onns with the accuracywithin an acceptable range. for instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33%accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (fcnn) and 74.88% area isreduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on resnet-32. However, this is notsufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we proposea novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deepreinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approachhas been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. Theproposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task andcan be trained in a fully supervised manner.

Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost,optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate foraccelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes aremodulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phasesare still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carryinformation for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose aframework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating inputimage data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input andoutput parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude andphase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures isintroduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that theproposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracywithin an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33%accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area isreduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is notsufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we proposea novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deepreinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approachhas been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. Theproposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task andcan be trained in a fully supervised manner.

The input andoutput parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude andphase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures isintroduced to maintain the accuracy. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications. Having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost, optical neural networks (ONNs) have emerged as a promising candidate for accelerating deep learning tasks. In conventional ONNs, light amplitudes are modulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the light phases are still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carry information for computing. To address this issue, in this paper, we propose a framework called OPLixNet to compress the areas of ONNs by modulating input image data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. The input and output parts of the ONNs are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude and phase information. Moreover, mutual learning across different ONN structures is introduced to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the areas of ONNs with the accuracy within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33% accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (FCNN) and 74.88% area is reduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on ResNet-32. However, this is not sufficient to achieve the goal of improving accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture to solve this problem by using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and neural network architecture search. This approach has been shown to outperform existing methods in both accuracy and speed. The proposed architecture can be applied to any deep reinforcement learning task and can be trained in a fully supervised manner. Furthermore, the proposed architecture is able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations quickly and efficiently. The proposed architecture is also able to learn from multiple environments simultaneously and can be used in a variety of applications.
